Article.ArticleTitle: Advanced oxidation of pharmaceuticals by the ozone-activated peroxymonosulfate process: the role of different oxidative species.

AbstractText: Given the need for innovations in advanced oxidation processes to deal with challenges such as OH scavenging, this paper addresses the removal of pharmaceuticals with a large variety in ozone reactivity (k<sub>O3</sub> = 0.15-3 × 10<sup>5</sup> M<sup>-1</sup>s<sup>-1</sup>) by use of the novel ozone-activated peroxymonosulfate (O<sub>3</sub>/PMS) process. A clear improvement in removal efficiency (up to 5 times higher) is noticed as a result of the generation of SO<sub>4</sub>- radicals, mainly for slow-ozone reacting compounds (k<sub>O3</sub> ≤ 250 M<sup>-1</sup>s<sup>-1</sup>) and in the presence of a OH scavenger. Depending on the target compound, SO<sub>4</sub>- are assessed to contribute for 50-90% to the overall removal of the micropollutants, both in single-compound and mixture experiments. Ozone-based PMS activation occurs at neutral to alkaline pH and, in the presence of a OH scavenger, removal efficiencies during O<sub>3</sub>/PMS are up to 3 times higher than with the O<sub>3</sub>/H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> process. In optimizing the O<sub>3</sub>/PMS process, a trade-off has to made between the desired removal and the PMS:O<sub>3</sub> ratio. A molar ratio of 1:10 already results in a clear benefit compared to the ozonation process. Further increase of the PMS content up to a 1:1 ratio improved the removal by an additional factor of 1.3-1.5.
